utterances: There's a banner on Jihadi message boards that the video will be released, and you are correct, Alex, that we got an early version of the video.
This is something, you know, monitoring Jihadi message boards have been our subject for a long, long time.
Well, what group is this from?
Do you know?
Can you identify the particular group that released this thing?
The group that released the video is the Islamic State of Iraq.

Islamic State of Iraq is an umbrella insurgency group that contain different insurgency in Iraq and maybe the most important and the famous one is al-Qaida in Iraq, Al-Qaida in Iraq that used to be headed by Abu Musab Al-Zarqawi.
Clearly they have access or someone they know has access to these soldiers because they do have these ID tags from them.
It seems to me, anyway, to be clear evidence that it's a valid claim on these people's part that at least they have access to the soldiers.
They also show some other personal belongings, which we can't really tell if they really belong to the soldiers.
They show, for instance, Visa Card, MasterCard and other credit cards on the video.
However, the quality is not good enough and we can't determine the names on these credit cards.
It's a very difficult question, but how do you take this report from the AP that the claim is that they have executed all three of these soldiers?

The narrator indicates that the soldier has been killed and that is a response to the communicae that they had earlier on - I think it was in mid-May - that if the searches of the soldiers will not be stopped by the American military, they will execute the soldiers.
And that's what the video is basically claiming.
You know, I think that we cannot verify the information in the video.
You know, they don't show any evidence for the execution.
We do know that.
One of these three soldiers had been found dead, as you indicated.
And you know, information about the Islamic State of Iraq/al-Qaida in Iraq, we know that they usually killed many of their hostages.
I actually do not remember a case that someone who was kidnapped by this group stayed alive.
However, everything is possible.
Again, there is no evidence in the video that the soldiers are dead.
It's just a claim that they had.
Rita Katz of the SITE Institute in Washington, D.C., a site that monitors the terrorist videos.
Rita, thank you for being with us on DAY TO DAY.
Thank you.
My pleasure.
This is NEWS & NOTES, I'm Ed Gordon.
On today's roundtable, ousted HealthSouth CEO Richard Scrushy allegedly pays for positive news stories.
And Harry Bellafante speaks out again.
Joining us to talk about these topics and more, from New York, Walter Fields, CEO and Publisher of the NorthStarNetwork.com.
Laura Washington joins us from Chicago.
She's a Chicago Sun columnist, and she's at member station WRLN, oh, in Miami today.
You moved on me today, Laura.
Yeah.
LRN.
And from Laurel, Maryland, George Curry, editor-in-chief of the National Newspaper Publishers Association.
Let's talk a little bit about something that made the news today.
Walter, we've been looking at this time and time again from different companies, and yet again Ford Motor Company suggesting that we're going to see upwards to 4,000 jobs lost.

One has to continue to take a look at the automobile industry that really, to a great degree, has been the foundation of the American economy for decades and decades and centuries, quite frankly, and particularly, within the African-American community has been a stronghold of jobs and wellbeing and wherewithal.
What does this, again, say for the ability for African-Americans to continue to move forward?
Well, it's an alarming trend.

I mean, these companies help move many blacks into the middle class with good waged jobs, good benefits and really, lifetime security, and now you're seeing the auto industry decimated, some of it by their own doing.

I mean, if you look at Ford, the fact that they really bet the ranch on SUVs at a time when the oil industry was really unstable and the fact that now you see this downward trend in sales that's causing them to take these drastic measures.
Then you have the free trade agreements that were struck with the auto industry.
We had a lot of the manufacturing exported outside of the country.
So it's sort of a double whammy, particularly for blacks in the auto industry.
And Ford is not the only automaker that's going through this, US automaker.

If you look at all of the automakers in the United States, the ones that are doing exceptionally well are, continue to be the Japanese automakers because they're producing cars that are fuel efficient, that are attractive in design and that consumers want.
The US auto industry is really lagging in many respects.
Yeah.
I think the agency was a bit sloppy after 9/11, and I'm sure they paid attention to that.
If this were to happen again, I suspect they will be somewhat better at it.
Jimmy, thanks very much for the phone call.
Joining me today top executives from the Big Three will discuss what's ahead for America's car companies.
Rod Gillum, vice president of corporate responsibility and diversity of General Motors is here.
From Chrysler, DaimlerChrysler, Frank Fountain, senior vice president, government affairs and Darryl Hazel, Ford Motor Company senior vice president and president of Ford customer service division.
Gentlemen, thank you so much for being with us.
Greatly appreciate it.
Mr.
Gillum, the idea that the auto industry of 25 years ago is completely different than the automobile industry we know today.
When you look at the challenges you face, how realistic is to believe that we're going to see the kind of muscle that we saw in its heyday?
Well, I think if you looked back, you would expect us to change.
We have a lot more competitors than we had before.
They're much better.
There are several new entries into the market coming every single year.
I think if you look at General Motors and where - we'll be celebrating 100 years of existence in a couple years - I think we have a proud, rich addition.
We do plan on being around, Ed.
I think contrary to some people that GM no longer has the halo that it had at one time, we continue to grow with the company globally.
We clearly have issues here in North America, but those are product driven, and we think that we've got the right team in place and the right products in place to turn that all around.
Is it hard for you to believe that we'd be talking about GM in the tenuous economic terms that we are.
Had you said that 25 years ago, I don't think anyone would have believed it.
Well, 25, 30 years ago, the government was looking to break to General Motors up because of antitrust concerns, and we were too large.

Quite frankly, looking back, that would be a great problem to have today, but I think, clearly, from our perspective, with the number of new entries into the market, there's just no way that one company can preserve that share of dominance in the marketplace.
Competition has made us a better company as well.
We think the offerings today are much more exciting and much more diverse than they used to be.
We understand the importance of quality and on all of our - all the rounders, all the external indexes, JD Powers and others, GM is right there at the one or two position.
Darryl Hazel, let me turn my attention to you.
Ford Motor Company, over the course of the last couple of weeks announcing more job cuts.
People concerned, particularly in these regions, just sustaining a lifestyle.
We heard from President Bush - I asked this of the mayor.
I ask it of you: do you think it's realistic that car companies, the U.S.
Big Three can survive without federal help?
Oh, I certainly think that we won't only survive.
We'll prosper.
Even in today's environment, the car business is an integral part of anyone's economy.
Any emerging country, one of the first things they do is try to establish their own car industry, and of course, where do they want to sell those cars?
Right here.
Why?
Because it's the most profitable market in the world to be in.
And as the home teams, yes, we have to do some things to effectively compete across the globe, but this still remains the largest market, and we certainly intend to get our unfair share of it.
Frank Fountain, how much is it fair to criticize the car companies and say that the Big Three got fat.
They got egotistical.
They never believed that they would have to be in real competition with anyone other than the other two?
Mr.
W.
FRANK FOUNTAIN, Jr. (Senior Vice President, Government Affairs, DaimlerChrysler): Well, fairness is a...
Is a relative term.
I will take that.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Is a relative term.
I think that the automobile industry has gone through cycles just like the banking industry, the textile industry and many other industries.
It's a dynamic world.
It's a global economy, and we have - there's globally competition, and so I think the auto industry isn't just the facilities and the headquarters here in Detroit.

The auto industry has a presence in almost every state and city in this country and is a major part of the fabric of the economies throughout the U.S., and I think the auto industry and its contribution to this country's economy is very much misunderstood, especially when it compares to foreign facilities in this country.
You want to say - you want to follow-up?
No, and I think that the number of jobs that just one of the three companies provide is greater than the sum of all of the jobs provided by, whether it's the Japanese or the other auto companies.
Rod Gillum, isn't that the key, though, particularly for African- Americans?
I sit here with three black males who are high executives in these corporations.
The auto industry has provided great opportunity for African- Americans.

If we all concede that we're going to have to see leaner companies, that's going to mean downsizing these companies where even if you get back to full strength, you're probably not going to be able to employ the people that you let go, number to number.
That being said, how should African-Americans look at this?
You know, Ed, I think that it concerns me personally.
My father came from the South to the North to work at an assembly plant, spent 27 years and retired from there, and today I'm a vice president at General Motors.
So clearly, my family's success has been by virtue of the contribution of the auto industry.
I think that what we've got to focus on is how to turn the business around to grow market share to let us continue to be able to contribute to those communities as we have in the past.

In pains me to see some of the urban settings where we have to end up closing facilities, and those are the facilities where you have a number of African-American employees, and as a result of losing that market share to the imports primarily, it has the tremendous impact on the whole local economy.
I would love to be in a situation where we could increase the number of minority suppliers.
Today we have about $4.3 billion, and that's with a ""b"", in components that will go to minority suppliers.

If GM reduces, then that impacts those suppliers and in turn impacts their communities as well, so our desire is to turn the cycle around, increase our market share, therefore increase opportunities for employment, increase opportunities for suppliers and dealers as well.
Thank you.
I appreciate it.
(Soundbite of machinery)
Frank Fountain, this is a huge problem, though.
I don't know that America and perhaps even the auto industries have grappled with all of the challenges they face or even have a game plan fully to try to shore up the land that we stood on.

Are you concerned that, in terms of just African-Americans again, we may see in downsizing, some of those in the corporate suites go away and not be able to really bring the concerns of black America to the table when you talk about reshaping this industry?
Well, I think the African-American presence in the auto industry has been significant for many, many decades, and I don't see that changing.
I think the industry will obviously get, become more efficient, which means fewer employees to produce vehicles on the one hand.

On the other hand, I think the auto industry leads almost all other industries in this country in employment of African-Americans in providing - and the purchase of goods and services from African-American businesses.
I think we've been leaders in that.

I think that the industry, that African-Americans and their presence in their industry will continue to grow, I think, not withstanding the downsizing, and DaimlerChrysler over the last ten to 12 years has invested $6 billion in new facilities in the city of Detroit: new engine plants, new assembly plants and that is in the heart of where African-Americans live and work.

Darryl Hazel, what do you tell a guy that worked at a plant that made $12, $15 overtime, was able to buy a home, was able to send his kid to college, was able to eke out an existence and, in the best of times, live a true middle class existence in America?
What do you tell him that he's not going to, possibly, be able tell his kid who may not go to college, you too can have the same life.

Well, I, this is not a phenomenon that is only in the auto industry, and I would just say that, as a big supporter of education, the notion that you may not want to go to college, it's true there are a lot of people who don't; but as the global economy is moving, everybody is focusing more on education.
So, I would say that, that guy who is working in a plant, first off, he wasn't making $12 to $15; he was making considerable more than that.
And it did create a strong, vibrant middle class.
In fact, America's still the only economy that is truly driven by its middle class; and we just have to adapt.
Just because the solution may not be crystal clear doesn't mean there isn't a viable one out there.
I'd also like to say, relative to your earlier point about the role and influence of African Americans, I see it continuing to increase.
What you're seeing now is more African Americans involved in the design of vehicles.
Why?
Because African- American culture is one of the leading cultures of our society and you're going to see more of that, not less.
Frank, can you suggest that that is going to be the case when, for instance, Chrysler is now Daimler-Chrysler.
There are those that will say that it's not fully part of the Big Three in the sense of the American Big Three anymore.
Is that the wave of the future; and are we going to see that kind of influence, a European influence?
And what will that do?
There are different sensibilities, as we know, that come to the table when someone else is in play.
Well, I think, Ed, the merger between Daimler, Benz and Chrysler Corporation has proven to be a successful merger.
I think its impact on African Americans within the company and other minorities has been a positive one.
I think that the German-American mixture of cultures within the company has also proven to be a successful undertaking.

And as a result of that, we have promoted, continued to promote African Americans within the Chrysler Group; and every other metric that one would look at to see what has happened over the last five years, since the merger, would be a positive.
As General Motors moves to morph itself into whatever it's going to become in terms of a corporation, Rod, I know that you've heard this.
There are those, the blue-collar worker, who says the execs in the Ivory Tower don't get it; and they don't understand that it's not going to come back.
You're painting too rosy of a picture and we're just out of luck.
We're going to have to take our behinds to Wal-Mart, no benefits, and hope that we can survive.
What do you tell them?
I think it's a very difficult message.
The reality is that, in certain parts of the world, we clearly are getting smaller.
And the solution, of course, is having the right products, having the right management team in place, having the right technologies.
And, you know, no one wants to downsize.
And I think it's something that hurts all of us, quite frankly.
But that blue-collar worker I would ask him or her to hold on.
You know, Darryl mentioned that there are certain cycles in this business.
We're at a low spot right now; and we think that we've turned the corner.
You look at market share increase, in just the month of January, we were up six percent.
So, we feel very optimistic about the future.
We have launched some new products, which we think are the best in the class.
We have 20 products that have more than 20 miles per gallon.
Most people don't know about that.
So, we need to do a better job of telling that story.
Darryl, can you compete with foreign competition?
We know through the years there was a question about whether or not there was an equal playing field for the American car companies.
Where do you stand today?
Can you actually step in the ring and go toe-to-toe now?
Well, that's what this whole thing has been all about.
As I said earlier, the domestic industry here in the United States is still the one everyone aspires to enter.

And I don't know how many people truly understand that particularly the traditional domestic three are the ones that fund the pensions; are the ones that fund the healthcare; are the ones that supply a lot of capital to various charities throughout America.
And I don't think that the consumer wants to make a choice based on that.
So, it does come down to the product; but there is no reason why we can't get the product to where we want it to be.
And we're all working very hard to do just that.
Frank Fountain, is the president realistic in saying don't look to us for help?
Because as Darryl Hazel just suggested, when you look at the tentacles that the automobile industry has in the U.S.
economy; it would be hard to fathom the U.S.
economy staying strong without out a strong presence.
